World Cup.passage: The FIFA World Cup, often simply called the World Cup, is an international association football competition contested by the senior men's national teams of the members of the Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA), the sport's global governing body. The championship has been awarded every four years since the inaugural tournament in 1930, except in 1942 and 1946 when it was not held because of the Second World War. The current champion is France, which won its second title at the 2018 tournament in Russia. The World Cup is the most prestigious association football tournament in the world, as well as the most widely viewed and followed sporting event in the world, exceeding even the Olympic Games. The cumulative audience of all matches of the 2006 World Cup was estimated to be 26.29 billion with an estimated 715.1 million people watching the final match, a ninth of the entire population of the planet. The 2010 World Cup in South Africa was broadcast to 204 countries on 245 different channels. The World Cup is held in a different country every four years. The host country is chosen by FIFA's Council, which is composed of representatives from each of the six regional confederations, and the decision is usually made six years before the tournament is scheduled to take place. The tournament consists of two stages: the group stage and the knockout stage. In the group stage, the 32 teams are divided into eight groups of four teams each, where each team plays the other three teams in its group once. The top two teams from each group advance to the knockout stage, which consists of a single-elimination tournament culminating in the final match. The World Cup has a rich history, with many memorable moments and legendary players. Some of the most famous moments in World Cup history include Diego Maradona's "Hand of God" goal in the 1986 quarterfinals, Zinedine Zidane's headbutt in the 2006 final, and the "Miracle of Bern" in 1954, when West Germany defeated Hungary in the final after being down 2-0 at halftime. Some of the most famous players in World Cup history include Pelé, Maradona, Johan Cruyff, Franz Beckenbauer, Ronaldo, and Lionel Messi. The World Cup has also had a significant impact on the countries that have hosted it.

Olympics.passage: The Olympics, also known as the Olympic Games, is a major international multi-sport event that takes place every four years. The event brings together athletes from all over the world to compete in a variety of sports, including athletics, swimming, gymnastics, and many others. The modern Olympic Games were first held in Athens, Greece in 1896, and have since become one of the most prestigious and widely watched sporting events in the world. The Olympics are governed by the International Olympic Committee (IOC), which is responsible for selecting the host city for each Games, as well as overseeing the organization and management of the event. The IOC is made up of representatives from various national Olympic committees, and is headquartered in Lausanne, Switzerland. The Olympic Games are divided into two main categories: the Summer Olympics and the Winter Olympics. The Summer Olympics feature a wide range of sports, including track and field, swimming, diving, gymnastics, basketball, soccer, and many others. The Winter Olympics, on the other hand, focus on sports that are typically played in colder climates, such as skiing, snowboarding, ice hockey, and figure skating. The Olympic Games have a long and storied history, and have been the site of many memorable moments and achievements. Some of the most famous Olympic moments include Jesse Owens' four gold medals at the 1936 Berlin Games, Nadia Comaneci's perfect 10 in gymnastics at the 1976 Montreal Games, and Michael Phelps' record-breaking 23 gold medals over the course of his Olympic career. In addition to the athletic competitions, the Olympic Games also feature a number of cultural events and ceremonies. The opening and closing ceremonies are particularly notable, and often feature elaborate performances and displays of national pride and identity. Overall, the Olympic Games are a celebration of athleticism, international cooperation, and cultural exchange. They bring together people from all over the world to compete, learn, and grow, and serve as a reminder of the power of sport to unite and inspire.

Super Bowl.passage: The Super Bowl is the annual championship game of the National Football League (NFL), the highest level of professional American football in the United States. The game is played between the winners of the AFC and NFC conferences, and is the culmination of a season that begins in the late summer of the previous year. The first Super Bowl was played in 1967, and since then it has become one of the most watched television events in the world. The game is typically held on the first Sunday in February, and is watched by millions of people around the globe. The Super Bowl is more than just a football game, however. It has become a cultural phenomenon, with millions of people tuning in to watch the halftime show, which features some of the biggest names in music and entertainment. The commercials that air during the game have also become a major part of the event, with companies spending millions of dollars to air their ads during the game. The Super Bowl has also become a major betting event, with millions of dollars wagered on the outcome of the game each year. In addition, the game has become a major tourism event, with thousands of people traveling to the host city each year to attend the game and the various events that surround it. Despite its popularity, the Super Bowl has not been without controversy. In recent years, there has been growing concern over the long-term health effects of playing football, and some have called for the game to be banned altogether. In addition, there have been concerns over the impact of the game on the environment, with some criticizing the massive amounts of energy and resources that are used to host the event. Despite these concerns, however, the Super Bowl remains one of the most popular and beloved events in American culture. It is a celebration of football, of American culture, and of the human spirit, and it is sure to continue to captivate audiences for many years to come.

UEFA Champions League.passage: The UEFA Champions League is an annual football competition organized by the Union of European Football Associations (UEFA). It is one of the most prestigious club competitions in the world, featuring the top football clubs from Europe. The competition was first held in 1955, and it has since grown to become one of the most popular and widely watched sporting events in the world. The competition is open to the top football clubs from the various European leagues, with the number of teams from each country determined by their UEFA coefficient ranking. The competition begins with a group stage, where the teams are divided into groups of four and play each other twice. The top two teams from each group then progress to the knockout stage, which consists of two-legged ties, with the winner progressing to the next round. The final of the UEFA Champions League is one of the most watched sporting events in the world, with millions of viewers tuning in to watch the best teams in Europe battle it out for the coveted trophy. The final is typically held in May or June, and it is played at a neutral venue, with the location rotating between different cities across Europe. The UEFA Champions League has a rich history, with some of the greatest football clubs in the world having won the competition. Real Madrid is the most successful club in the history of the competition, having won the trophy a record 13 times. Other notable winners include Barcelona, Manchester United, Liverpool, AC Milan, and Bayern Munich. The UEFA Champions League is not only a showcase for the best football clubs in Europe, but it is also a platform for some of the world's best players to showcase their skills. The competition has seen some of the greatest players in history, including Lionel Messi, Cristiano Ronaldo, Zinedine Zidane, and Johan Cruyff, among others. In addition to the prestige of winning the UEFA Champions League, the competition also offers significant financial rewards for the participating clubs. The prize money for the 2020-21 season was €2.04 billion, with the winning club receiving €19 million in prize money alone. Overall, the UEFA Champions League is a truly global sporting event, with millions of fans tuning in from around the world to watch the best football clubs in Europe compete for glory. With its rich history, iconic moments, and legendary players, the competition is sure to continue to captivate football fans for many years to come.

NBA Finals.passage: The NBA Finals is the championship series of the National Basketball Association (NBA). The series was first played in 1947, and has been played annually since 1950. The winner of the NBA Finals is awarded the Larry O'Brien Championship Trophy, which replaced the Walter A. Brown Trophy in 1983. The NBA Finals is a best-of-seven series between the Eastern Conference and Western Conference champions. The series is played in a 2-2-1-1-1 format, with the team with the better regular season record hosting Games 1, 2, 5, and 7. The NBA Finals typically takes place in June, following the conclusion of the NBA playoffs. The Boston Celtics hold the record for the most NBA Finals championships, with 17. The Los Angeles Lakers are second with 16 championships, followed by the Chicago Bulls with 6 championships. The Golden State Warriors and San Antonio Spurs are tied for fourth with 5 championships each. The NBA Finals has produced some of the most memorable moments in basketball history. In 1998, Michael Jordan hit a game-winning shot in Game 6 of the Finals to secure the Chicago Bulls' sixth championship. In 2016, LeBron James led the Cleveland Cavaliers to their first championship in franchise history, coming back from a 3-1 deficit against the Golden State Warriors. The NBA Finals is also a major television event, with millions of viewers tuning in to watch the games. The series is broadcast on ABC in the United States, and is also shown in over 200 countries around the world. Overall, the NBA Finals is the culmination of the NBA season, and is a showcase for the best basketball players in the world. The series is a celebration of the sport, and a testament to the hard work and dedication of the players, coaches, and teams who compete for the championship.

FIFA Club World Cup.passage: The FIFA Club World Cup is an international men's association football competition organized by the Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA), the sport's global governing body. The tournament was first contested in 2000 as the FIFA Club World Championship. It was not held between 2001 and 2004 due to a combination of factors, most importantly the collapse of FIFA's marketing partner International Sport and Leisure. Since 2005, the competition has been held every year, and has been hosted by Brazil, Japan, the United Arab Emirates, Morocco, Qatar, and China. The tournament is contested by the champion clubs from the six continental confederations of FIFA, as well as the host nation's league champions. The current format of the competition involves seven teams competing in a knockout tournament, with the winner being crowned the FIFA Club World Cup champion. The most successful club in the history of the competition is Real Madrid, who have won the tournament four times. Other notable winners include Barcelona, Corinthians, and Bayern Munich, who have each won the tournament twice. The FIFA Club World Cup has been criticized for its lack of prestige and relevance, with many top European clubs choosing to prioritize domestic and continental competitions over the tournament. However, FIFA has made efforts to increase the profile of the competition, including expanding the number of teams and increasing the prize money. Despite these efforts, the FIFA Club World Cup remains a relatively minor competition in the global football calendar. However, it remains an important opportunity for clubs from smaller confederations to compete against the world's best teams, and for fans to see some of the sport's biggest stars in action.

Tour de France.passage: The Tour de France is an annual men's multiple stage bicycle race primarily held in France, while also occasionally making passes through nearby countries. First staged in 1903, the race covers more than 3,500 kilometres (2,200 mi) throughout France and has become one of the most prestigious and grueling events in the sport of cycling. The race is broken into daily stages, with each stage covering a different distance and terrain, and the overall winner being determined by the cumulative time taken to complete all stages. The Tour de France is typically held in July and attracts the world's top cyclists, who compete for the coveted yellow jersey, awarded to the overall race leader. The race is organized by the Amaury Sport Organisation, which also manages other major cycling events such as Paris-Roubaix and the Vuelta a España. The Tour de France has a rich history, with many legendary cyclists having won the race multiple times. The most successful rider in the history of the race is Belgian cyclist Eddy Merckx, who won the Tour de France five times between 1969 and 1974. Other notable winners include French riders Jacques Anquetil and Bernard Hinault, American cyclist Lance Armstrong, and British rider Chris Froome. The race is known for its grueling mountain stages, which often feature steep climbs and treacherous descents. These stages are often the most decisive in determining the overall winner of the race, as they require a combination of strength, endurance, and tactical skill. In addition to the yellow jersey, other jerseys are awarded to riders who excel in specific areas of the race. The green jersey is awarded to the rider who accumulates the most points in the sprint stages, while the polka dot jersey is awarded to the best climber in the mountain stages. The white jersey is awarded to the best young rider under the age of 25. Australian Open.passage: The Australian Open is a major tennis tournament held annually in Melbourne, Australia. It is one of the four Grand Slam tournaments, along with the French Open, Wimbledon, and the US Open. The tournament is held over two weeks in January, and features both men's and women's singles, doubles, and mixed doubles events. The Australian Open was first held in 1905, and has been held annually since then, with the exception of a few years during World War I and World War II. The tournament was originally played on grass courts, but switched to hard courts in 1988. The tournament is held at Melbourne Park, which has a total of 24 courts, including three main show courts: Rod Laver Arena, Margaret Court Arena, and Melbourne Arena. Rod Laver Arena is the largest of the three, with a seating capacity of over 15,000. The Australian Open has a reputation for being one of the most player-friendly Grand Slam tournaments, with excellent facilities and a relaxed atmosphere. The tournament is also known for its extreme heat, with temperatures often reaching over 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit) during the day. The men's singles event has been dominated in recent years by Novak Djokovic, who has won the tournament a record nine times. Other notable winners include Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, and Pete Sampras. In the women's singles event, Serena Williams has won the tournament seven times, while other notable winners include Margaret Court, Steffi Graf, and Martina Navratilova. The Australian Open is also known for its innovative use of technology, including the introduction of the Hawk-Eye system for line calls in 2006. The tournament was also the first Grand Slam to introduce electronic line calling on all courts in 2021. Overall, the Australian Open is a highly respected and prestigious tennis tournament, and is considered one of the highlights of the tennis calendar. Its unique location, player-friendly atmosphere, and innovative use of technology make it a must-see event for tennis fans around the world.

NFL playoffs.passage: The NFL playoffs are a single-elimination tournament held after the regular season to determine the champion of the National Football League (NFL). The playoffs consist of four rounds, with the top six teams from each conference (the AFC and NFC) qualifying for the postseason. The two top-seeded teams from each conference receive a bye in the first round, while the remaining four teams play in the wild card round. The wild card round consists of two games in each conference, with the third-seeded team hosting the sixth-seeded team and the fourth-seeded team hosting the fifth-seeded team. The winners of these games advance to the divisional round, where they face the top-seeded team in their conference. The second-seeded team hosts the other divisional round game. The winners of the divisional round games advance to the conference championships, which determine the AFC and NFC champions. The highest remaining seed hosts the lower-seeded team in each conference championship game. The winners of these games advance to the Super Bowl, which is held on the first Sunday in February and is the championship game of the NFL. The NFL playoffs have been held since 1933, and the current format was adopted in 1990. The playoffs have been expanded several times over the years, with the addition of wild card teams and the creation of the current four-round format. The Super Bowl has become one of the most-watched television events in the world, with millions of viewers tuning in each year to watch the game and the halftime show. The NFL playoffs are known for their high level of intensity and drama, with teams fighting for their chance to win the championship. The playoffs are also a time for fans to come together and cheer on their favorite teams, with many cities hosting watch parties and other events during the postseason. The NFL playoffs are a true spectacle of American sports, and they continue to captivate audiences around the world year after year.

The World Cup.passage: The FIFA World Cup, often simply called the World Cup, is an international association football competition contested by the senior men's national teams of the members of the Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA), the sport's global governing body. The championship has been awarded every four years since the inaugural tournament in 1930, except in 1942 and 1946 when it was not held because of the Second World War. The current champion is France, which won its second title at the 2018 tournament in Russia. The World Cup is the most prestigious association football tournament in the world, as well as the most widely viewed and followed sporting event in the world, exceeding even the Olympic Games. The cumulative audience of all matches of the 2006 World Cup was estimated to be 26.29 billion with an estimated 715.1 million people watching the final match, a ninth of the entire population of the planet. The 2010 World Cup in South Africa was broadcast to 204 countries on 245 different channels. The World Cup is held every four years, with the exception of 1942 and 1946, when it was cancelled due to World War II. The tournament consists of two stages: the group stage and the knockout stage. In the group stage, teams are divided into groups of four, with each team playing the other three teams in their group once. The top two teams from each group advance to the knockout stage, which consists of a single-elimination tournament. The winner of the final match is crowned the World Cup champion. The World Cup has a rich history, with many memorable moments and legendary players. Some of the most famous moments in World Cup history include Diego Maradona's "Hand of God" goal in the 1986 quarterfinals, Zinedine Zidane's headbutt in the 2006 final, and the "Miracle of Bern" in 1954, when West Germany defeated Hungary in the final after being down 2-0 at halftime. The World Cup has also been the stage for some of the greatest players in football history. Pele, Diego Maradona, Zinedine Zidane, Ronaldo, and Lionel Messi are just a few of the players who have left their mark on the tournament. The World Cup has also been the stage for some of the greatest teams in football history, including Brazil's 1970 team, which is widely regarded as one of the greatest teams of all time.

Ryder Cup.passage: The Ryder Cup is a biennial men's golf competition between teams from Europe and the United States. The competition is contested every two years with the venue alternating between courses in the United States and Europe. The Ryder Cup is named after the English businessman Samuel Ryder who donated the trophy. The event is jointly administered by the PGA of America and Ryder Cup Europe, the latter a joint venture of the PGA European Tour (60%), the PGA of Great Britain and Ireland (20%), and the PGA of Europe (20%). The competition began in 1927, and except for a period during World War II, has been held every two years since. The Ryder Cup is one of the world's most prestigious golf events and is considered by many to be the most prestigious team event in golf. The competition is known for its intense atmosphere and passionate crowds, with players often describing it as the most pressure-packed event they play in. The format of the Ryder Cup has evolved over the years, but the current format consists of 28 matches played over three days. On the first two days, there are four four-ball matches and four foursome matches, with each match worth one point. On the final day, there are 12 singles matches, with each match worth one point. The team with the most points at the end of the competition wins the Ryder Cup. The United States dominated the early years of the competition, winning 18 of the first 23 events. However, since the 1980s, Europe has been the dominant force, winning 11 of the last 16 events. FIFA World Cup.passage: The FIFA World Cup, often simply called the World Cup, is an international association football competition contested by the senior men's national teams of the members of the Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA), the sport's global governing body. The championship has been awarded every four years since the inaugural tournament in 1930, except in 1942 and 1946 when it was not held because of the Second World War. The current champion is France, which won its second title at the 2018 tournament in Russia. The World Cup is the most prestigious association football tournament in the world, as well as the most widely viewed and followed sporting event in the world, exceeding even the Olympic Games. The cumulative audience of all matches of the 2006 World Cup was estimated to be 26.29 billion with an estimated 715.1 million people watching the final match, a ninth of the entire population of the planet. The 2010 World Cup in South Africa was broadcast to 204 countries on 245 different channels. The World Cup is held in a different country every four years. The host country is chosen by FIFA's Council, which is composed of representatives from each of the six regional confederations. The selection process for the host country is highly competitive, with many countries vying for the opportunity to host the tournament. The host country is responsible for providing the infrastructure necessary to host the tournament, including stadiums, transportation, and accommodations for the teams and fans. The tournament consists of 32 teams, which are divided into eight groups of four teams each. The teams in each group play a round-robin tournament, with each team playing the other three teams in the group once. The top two teams from each group advance to the knockout stage of the tournament, which consists of a single-elimination tournament. The winner of the final match is crowned the World Cup champion. The World Cup has a rich history, with many memorable moments and legendary players. Some of the most famous moments in World Cup history include Diego Maradona's "Hand of God" goal in the 1986 tournament, Zinedine Zidane's headbutt in the 2006 final, and the "Miracle of Bern" in the 1954 final, when West Germany defeated Hungary to win their first World Cup. The World Cup is not only a sporting event, but also a cultural phenomenon. The tournament brings together people from all over the world to celebrate their love of football and their national pride.

MLB World Series.passage: The Major League Baseball (MLB) World Series is an annual championship series that determines the winner of the MLB season. Despite these changes, the World Series remains one of the most exciting and highly anticipated events in sports, drawing millions of viewers from around the world. In addition to the championship trophy, the World Series also awards the Most Valuable Player (MVP) award to the player who has the greatest impact on the series. Some of the most memorable MVP performances include Reggie Jackson's three home runs in Game 6 of the 1977 World Series and David Ortiz's clutch hitting in the 2013 World Series. The Masters (Golf).passage: The Masters Tournament, commonly referred to as simply The Masters, is one of the four major championships in professional golf. It is scheduled for the first full week of April and is the first of the majors to be played each year. Unlike the other major championships, the Masters is held annually at the same location, Augusta National Golf Club, a private golf club in the city of Augusta, Georgia, USA. The Masters was established in 1934 by Bobby Jones and Clifford Roberts. Jones designed Augusta National with course architect Alister MacKenzie. The tournament is an official money event on the PGA Tour, the European Tour, and the Japan Golf Tour. The field of players is smaller than those of the other major championships because it is an invitational event, held by the Augusta National Golf Club. The tournament has a number of traditions. Since 1949, a green jacket has been awarded to the champion, who must return it to the clubhouse one year after his victory, although it remains his personal property and is stored with other champions' jackets in a specially designated cloakroom. The Champions Dinner, inaugurated by Ben Hogan in 1952, is held on the Tuesday before each tournament, and is open only to past champions and certain board members of the Augusta National Golf Club. Beginning in 1963, legendary golfers, usually past champions, have hit an honorary tee shot on the morning of the first round to commence play. These have included Fred McLeod, Jock Hutchinson, Gene Sarazen, Sam Snead, Byron Nelson, Arnold Palmer, Jack Nicklaus, and Gary Player. The Masters has the smallest field of the major championships, with 90-100 players. Unlike other major championships, players who are not already qualified for the Masters must earn a place by one of several ways. The first is by winning one of the other major championships (the U.S. Open, The Open Championship, or the PGA Championship) or The Players Championship. The second is by winning one of the PGA Tour's other tournaments in the previous year. The third is by finishing in the top 50 on the Official World Golf Ranking at the end of the previous calendar year. Finally, the Augusta National Golf Club can invite international players who do not meet any of the other criteria. The Masters is widely considered to be one of the most prestigious golf tournaments in the world.

French Open (Tennis).passage: The French Open, also known as Roland Garros, is a major tennis tournament held annually in Paris, France. It is one of the four Grand Slam tournaments, along with the Australian Open, Wimbledon, and the US Open. The tournament is named after the French aviator Roland Garros, who was the first person to fly across the Mediterranean Sea. The French Open is played on clay courts, which are slower and more difficult to play on than other surfaces. This makes the tournament a unique challenge for players, as they must adjust their game to the slower pace of the clay. The tournament is held over two weeks in late May and early June, and features both men's and women's singles, doubles, and mixed doubles events. The French Open has a rich history, dating back to 1891 when it was first held. The tournament has been held at its current location, the Stade Roland Garros, since 1928. The stadium has undergone several renovations over the years, and now features 20 courts, including the main Philippe Chatrier Court, which has a seating capacity of over 15,000. The French Open has been won by some of the greatest players in tennis history, including Rafael Nadal, who has won the tournament a record 13 times. Other notable winners include Bjorn Borg, Chris Evert, Steffi Graf, and Roger Federer. The tournament has also been the site of some of the most memorable matches in tennis history, including the 1984 final between John McEnroe and Ivan Lendl, and the 1999 final between Andre Agassi and Andrei Medvedev. In addition to the tennis, the French Open is also known for its fashion and style. The tournament is a showcase for the latest trends in tennis apparel, and many players and fans alike dress up for the occasion. The tournament also features a variety of food and drink options, including traditional French cuisine and champagne. Overall, the French Open is one of the most prestigious and exciting events in the world of tennis. Its unique clay courts, rich history, and glamorous atmosphere make it a must-see for tennis fans and sports enthusiasts alike.

Stanley Cup (Hockey).passage: The Stanley Cup is a trophy awarded annually to the National Hockey League (NHL) playoff champion. It is the oldest existing trophy to be awarded to a professional sports franchise, and the International Ice Hockey Federation (IIHF) considers it to be one of the most important championships in the sport of ice hockey. The trophy was donated by Lord Stanley of Preston, the Governor General of Canada, in 1892. Originally, it was awarded to the top amateur hockey team in Canada, but in 1915, it was given exclusively to the NHL. Since then, the Cup has been awarded every year to the NHL playoff champion, with the exception of 2005, when the season was cancelled due to a labor dispute. The Stanley Cup is made of silver and nickel alloy, and stands 35.25 inches tall and weighs 34.5 pounds. The Cup is made up of three parts: the bowl, the bands, and the collar. The bowl is the main part of the trophy, and is where the names of the winning teams are engraved. The bands are added to the bowl as more names are added, and the collar is the top part of the trophy, which features the NHL logo and the names of the trustees who oversee the Cup. The Cup is unique in that it is not owned by any one team, but rather by the NHL. The winning team is allowed to keep the Cup for a year, and each player on the winning team gets to spend a day with the Cup, taking it wherever they want and doing whatever they want with it. This tradition has led to some interesting and unusual stories over the years, such as players taking the Cup to their hometowns, on fishing trips, and even to the top of mountains. The Stanley Cup playoffs are a grueling and intense competition, with 16 teams competing in a best-of-seven series to determine the champion. The playoffs are divided into four rounds: the first round, the conference semifinals, the conference finals, and the Stanley Cup Finals. The team that wins the Finals is awarded the Cup, and the players and coaches are given championship rings to commemorate their victory. The Stanley Cup has become an iconic symbol of hockey, and is revered by players and fans alike. Its rich history and tradition make it one of the most coveted trophies in all of sports, and winning it is the ultimate goal for any NHL team.

Europe..passage: Europe is a continent located entirely in the Northern Hemisphere and mostly in the Eastern Hemisphere. It is bordered by the Arctic Ocean to the north, the Atlantic Ocean to the west, and the Mediterranean Sea to the south. It comprises the westernmost part of Eurasia. Since around 1850, Europe is most commonly considered to be separated from Asia by the watershed divides of the Ural and Caucasus Mountains, the Ural River, the Caspian and Black Seas, and the waterways of the Turkish Straits. Although the term "continent" implies physical geography, the land border is somewhat arbitrary and has moved since its first conception in classical antiquity. The division of Eurasia into two continents reflects East-West cultural, linguistic, and ethnic differences, some of which vary on a spectrum rather than with a sharp dividing line. The border does not follow political boundaries, with Turkey, Russia, and Kazakhstan being transcontinental countries. Europe covers about 10,180,000 square kilometres (3,930,000 sq mi), or 2% of the Earth's surface (6.8% of land area), making it the second smallest continent (using the seven-continent model). Politically, Europe is divided into about fifty sovereign states of which the Russian Federation is the largest and most populous, spanning 39% of the continent and comprising 15% of its population. Europe had a total population of about 741 million (about 11% of the world population) as of 2018.

Los Angeles Lakers..passage: The Los Angeles Lakers are an American professional basketball team based in Los Angeles. The Lakers compete in the National Basketball Association (NBA) as a member of the league's Western Conference Pacific Division. The Lakers play their home games at Staples Center, an arena shared with the NBA's Los Angeles Clippers, the Los Angeles Sparks of the Women's National Basketball Association, and the Los Angeles Kings of the National Hockey League. The Lakers are one of the most successful teams in the history of the NBA, and have won 17 NBA championships, tied with the Boston Celtics for the most in NBA history. The franchise began with the 1947 purchase of a disbanded team, the Detroit Gems of the National Basketball League (NBL). The new team began playing in Minneapolis, Minnesota, calling themselves the Minneapolis Lakers. Initially a member of the NBL, the Lakers won the 1948 NBL championship before joining the rival Basketball Association of America, where they would win five of the next six championships, led by star George Mikan. After struggling financially in the late 1950s following Mikan's retirement, they relocated to Los Angeles before the 1960–61 season. Led by Hall of Famers Elgin Baylor and Jerry West, Los Angeles made the NBA Finals six times in the 1960s, but lost each series to the Celtics, beginning their long and storied rivalry. In 1972, the Lakers won their sixth championship, led by Wilt Chamberlain, Jerry West, and Gail Goodrich, who were known for their fast break offense. The team featured Hall of Famers in Chamberlain, West, and coach Pat Riley, and a Hall of Fame broadcaster in Chick Hearn. After the retirement of West and Chamberlain, the team acquired another center, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who had won multiple MVP awards, but was unable to make the Finals in the late 1970s. The 1980s Lakers were nicknamed "Showtime" due to their fast break-offense led by Magic Johnson. The team won five championships in a nine-year span, and contained Hall of Famers Johnson, Abdul-Jabbar, and James Worthy, and was led by Hall of Fame coach Pat Riley. After Abdul-Jabbar and Johnson retired, the team struggled in the early 1990s, before acquiring Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant in 1996.

Alister MacKenzie..passage: Alister MacKenzie (30 August 1870 – 6 January 1934) was a British golf course architect whose course designs span four continents. Originally trained as a surgeon, MacKenzie served as a civilian doctor with the British army during the Boer War where he first became interested in golf. After the war, he resumed his medical career but gradually turned to golf course design, partnering with Harry Colt and Charles Alison to form one of the most successful golf course design firms of the early 20th century. MacKenzie is best known for his work on Augusta National Golf Club, home of the Masters Tournament, which he co-designed with Bobby Jones. He also designed Cypress Point Club, Royal Melbourne Golf Club, and Pasatiempo Golf Club, among others. MacKenzie was a proponent of naturalistic golf course design, emphasizing the use of the existing terrain and features to create strategic and visually appealing holes. He wrote several books on golf course design, including "Golf Architecture: Economy in Course Construction and Green-Keeping" which is still considered a classic in the field. MacKenzie died in 1934 at the age of 63, but his legacy lives on through his many influential golf course designs.

Mediterranean Sea..passage: The Mediterranean Sea is a sea connected to the Atlantic Ocean, surrounded by the Mediterranean Basin and almost completely enclosed by land: on the north by Southern Europe and Anatolia, on the south by North Africa, and on the east by the Levant. Although the sea is sometimes considered a part of the Atlantic Ocean, it is usually referred to as a separate body of water. Geological evidence indicates that around 5.9 million years ago, the Mediterranean was cut off from the Atlantic and was partly or completely desiccated over a period of some 600,000 years before being refilled by the Zanclean flood about 5.3 million years ago. It covers an approximate area of 2.5 million km² (965,000 sq mi), but its connection to the Atlantic (the Strait of Gibraltar) is only 14 km (8.7 mi) wide. In oceanography, it is sometimes called the Eurafrican Mediterranean Sea or the European Mediterranean Sea to distinguish it from mediterranean seas elsewhere. The Mediterranean Sea has an average depth of 1,500 m (4,900 ft) and the deepest recorded point is 5,267 m (17,280 ft) in the Calypso Deep in the Ionian Sea. The sea is bordered on the north by Europe, the east by Asia, and in the south by Africa. It is located between latitudes 30° and 46° N and longitudes 6° W and 36° E. Its west-east length, from the Strait of Gibraltar to the Gulf of Iskenderun, on the southwestern coast of Turkey, is approximately 4,000 km (2,500 miles).
